lines.text: Ooh, what I heard about you in Paris, ooh.
And of course, like a true knight, you refused to believe it.
Well, the first six or seven hundred times I did.
I'm in an orgy, wallowing, and I love it.
I'm wild for you but I am a gentleman.
That's a wonderful combination.
We mix a lot of things but we take our women straight.
Women like you won't do. I won't spend the rest of my life looking at shadows on the wall.
And now for the wicked city.
And a struggle for life, liberty and elbow room.
Ha-ha. With 8 million slaves. Gosh, how I hate it.
We're the only free ones! Us two.
And thus we'll stay.
Yes sir!
Come on, be the big broad-minded type, let's take Stevie along. What do you say?
If I could invent a cream that would make 37 look like 17, I'd use it myself!
Have a grand time?
Oh, seventh heaven... eighth, if there is one...
So, you still love him?
Oh, more than the earth, the sun, the moon or the stars - with the Milky Way thrown in for good measure.
My dear child, if you feel that way, why don't you marry him? Well, why don't you?
We don't believe in the awful necessity of marriage.
You mean, he doesn't.
I mean what I said.

[singing]
Celia loves me, that I know, much obliged to Celia...
And, by the way, when did you go conventional?
When I got sense. At present I'm carrying on a purely plutonic affair with a very rich man. Plutonic.
You're funny.
No, clever. I'll marry him someday. Unless he's smarter than I am.
Ha-ha. He isn't.
Steve will be like that after you two have been married a year or so.
Us married? Haven' t you heard? There's a goof named Alan.
Who is he?
He's the fly in the ointment. In fact, the ointment is practically all flies.
Well, what is he?
Well, your honor, it's this way. You see, he writes.
A foreign correspondent.
In a big way!
One of those guys who's always horning in on revolutions. Having breakfast with Mussolini.
Wherever there's trouble in the world, he goes sits among it.
And no more home ties than a floating kidney.
Oh, but, seriously, I don't mean to be prying, but if your mother was still alive.
Dear Aunt Celia, I'm free, white and twenty-one.
Sound in wind and limb.
Shut up. And I know my own mind.
Oh, New York's ruined her. She has a mind of her own.
Does he love you?
Well, if he doesn't, I'm just out of luck.
I think I better kidnap you. You sound a little mad.
Ha-ha. Well, it's nice to be a little mad about someone.
There's a broken heart for every light on Broadway.
So help me, Jemima, I've never seen New York so filthy with weather for such a stretch.

[singing]
And all the world is gay but me.
You're a great girl darling; but, you're a little bit dumb.

[Picks up the phone]
Yes, hello. Hello.
[to Geneva]
Long distance, Boston.
Steve? Tell him you'll marry him. It will help him over the holidays.
Ha-ha. Merry Christmas.
Merry Christmas.

[Talking on the phone to a drunk Steve]
Marry you? If you were here now and could stand up, I might. I said, I might.
I'll be there tomorrow. Sober as a judge.
Oh. And try to take me back to Boston? Pack me in mothballs? So you could come to New York with a bucket of red paint?
Well, for goodness sake, I thought you were in Timbuktu or the South Pole or some place?
Hello, Harry, I just got in.
Now, don't scold Harry, my mother brought me up to never be on time when you met a man.
Well, shades of Santa Claus!
Hello, Geneva
Have you phoned upstairs?
I just arrived.
Well, here's my key. Number three-ten. Now, don't phone and don't knock. Walk right in and say, eh, eh, Merry, eh, Fourth of July or Chinese New Year. Ha-ha.
Alan! Is Santa Claus doing tricks or are you real?
I'd hate terribly to hurt you.
Why, haven't you heard? Nowadays a girl may kiss - and ride on. Just as well as any man ever could.
Let's see.
No-no. You came to explain, not to make love.
Lisbeth, you're the darling of the world.
Ha-ha. And that's from an expert.
Gosh, you're lovely!
Ha-ha. And we can always be good friends?
Oh, yes.
It sounds like, fare-the-well.
It's wrong to end so sweet a chapter like this. I'm going to a charming spot. Where the sun is warm, no noise, no hurry. Lazy people play funny music in the moonlight.
No wonder you love your job.
Are you saying no?
Do you know you haven't kissed me?
Ha-ha. Why, so I haven't, have I?
You did, once or twice, you know.
Yes, but, I realize now we were - almost strangers.
And I didn't half know how marvelous you are.
Well, this is a swell time to come in. Eight o'clock in the morning.
That's exactly the way I feel. Been up to Harlem for ham and eggs.
Oh, don't they serve them locally, anymore?
Any use in my telling you that you're making a mistake? No, I didn't think there was.
No power on earth can stop me.
Thank goodness your laundry came back yesterday. I knew a girl who forgot all of her best underclothes. It practically ruined Niagara Falls.
Now my dear girl, Steve is a good lad. And you know, after all, marriage still is the natural...

Oh, quit will you! You make me sick! You think women should all be shoved into a coop - like hens. That is, good women! The only important thing you don't mention at all. You can't tell me anything! Women aren't human things to you! They're either wives or sweethearts! Get a house - and some furniture and some rugs and a wife!

Darling. Darling, you're right and I'm a fool. I'm sorry but you'll have to send your messages by wireless. No time now for sad farewells. Forget about tomorrow and yesterday and go to it. My wild Irish blessing's attend you. Hooray and three cheers!
I wish we'd been born here. If we had, I wonder what would have happened?
Well, some Saturday night I should probably have put on my best pair of velveteen panties, sneaked up under your window, sung a serenade and then said...
[Goat bleats]
Ha-ha. Or, words to that effect.
We're not talking of the same things. You, with your revolutions!
Gee whiz, Lisbeth. Talk about shocks.
Oh, but what a relief. Now you don't have to pack me in mothballs.
Oh, darling.
Because I've seen life murmur and heard it glisten. I'm no longer the good woman in your life, Stevie.
There are no good women.
Sorry to hear you say that.
Do you know I've followed you from London to Berlin, from Berlin to Monte Carlo...
Ha-ha. And here I am. So get your little surprise dance all calmed down. Let's celebrate.
Right-o. Lets.
You look awful good to me.
Ha-ha. It's simply gorgeous, Stevie, you bobbing up like this. Really, thrilling.
Oh, you're lying. But, I like it. I never gave you a thrill in your life.
I'm not lying. I try to find one kick for every 24 hours. You saved the day!
Well, that's something.

[Toast]
Happy days!
Here's mud in your eye.
What have they done to you, buddy?
Who wants to know?
Oh, come on now, come clean. It's your ol' pal.
Ha-ha. Don't worry about me. You see, I had a little bluebird, but no cage. Bluebird got away. Just a little gal who lost a bluebird.

What an afternoon you have missed. There are six bulls. Each one, each one the most vicious. And you wouldn't come. Game, unexciting roulette you like better than bullfighting. Six bulls. Scaritto, he scratches three. Three! Himself, nearly killed. How thrilling. Its too bad. Too bad.
Sounds like a lot of bull, eh, Steve?
Oh, yeah, you said it.
This dance is to educate you. How you should arouse a man.
Ha-ha. A man shouldn't need it.

Oh, look here Steve, what's the matter with you? You've been out for fun all your life. Ha-ha. All you men are. I found that out. The sweet grand things that a girl dreams about, don't interest men at all. They're just a nuisance.
Did you ever think that a two-fisted drinker wasn't the answer to my maiden's prayer?
Ha-ha. Come on, it's all a grand hoot and we're buddies, aren't we. Free as wildcats!
I was about to say something new. Deep and startling. Its the same old world it always was and it always will be.
Ha-ha. And life's like that.
Ain't it just.
You don't mind, do you Steve? I'd like to be alone. Just a little while.
Sure. If you want me, I'll be at Harry's Bar. After midnight, Zellies.
Oh, it's nice enough, but, I'm getting fed up on musical shows.
Oh, they're great for us tired business women.
Don't believe him. If legs were mathematics, he'd be a second Einstein.
There will always be a bottle of champagne, burning in the window.
